children.subject:
Don't be too fixated on "pursuing BAIR" whatever that means, find a professor that does research that you are interested in, and tailor your courseload for that. If you're interested in doing RL research, than 188 would be a great class; if you want to work with some of the more control theory type professors take 128, or somebody who's more into stochastic systems take 126. The value of the "BAIR" label probably isn't as important as you think (for undergraduates), and focus more on producing high quality research with whoever you're working with.

Additionally, I'm working with a few people within the labs of some faculty members in BAIR, but my name is not on the list, nor are some of the other people I know who's in a similar position.

history.content:
(this question is very late for its own reasons) If I'm thinking of pursuing BAIR in fall 2020, should I take CS170+EE126+Math 110, or CS170+CS188+Math 110 this semester?

This semester I will work with a PhD student for research and hopefully write a paper with him. I can also drop 110 from the first schedule before the drop deadline if I think it's hard with 170 126 and research. I have research experience starting from fall 2019.

The PhD student recommended 126. 

I was also thinking 188 might be very helpful for getting into BAIR, but the latter schedule is lighter for a spring semester schedule, and I'm not sure when I would take 126 afterwards.

I'm registered in all 4 classes right now and doing work for all four, although primarily for 126 170.
history.subject: BAIR in Fall 2020
